newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland must double defence spending - president.
newsitem.headline: Poland must double defence spending - president.

text.p: Poland will have to double its current spending on military modernisation to meet its future NATO obligations, President Aleksander Kwasniewski said on Monday.

"There is a need, over the five years from 1998 to 2002, at least to double spending for modernisation of the army if we are to be a serious partner for NATO structures," Kwasniewski told an annual conference of Polish military chiefs in Warsaw.
"This is a sum of eight billion zlotys ($2.85 billion)," public television showed him telling the conference.
He later told a news conference that one approach could be to create a special modernisation fund for the forces.
Poland earmarked nearly eight billion zlotys for defence this year out of total 1996 budget spending of 111.6 billion zlotys.
The government is just about to submit proposals for next year's budget.

Although parliament last year adopted a resolution calling for defence spending to be increased to three percent of gross domestic product by 1997, Kwasniewski said this goal would be beyond Poland's economic possiblities.

The two-day conference, continuing on Tuesday and gathering around 180 top military officers, is to discuss reforms including a streamlining of the general staff through splitting off a separate land forces command.
The changes, partly aimed at ensuring better civilian control, could mean job cuts at the top of the military and have caused concern in the forces.
Defence Minister Stanislaw Dobrzanski said they would not be hasty.

"We will carry out such reforms but we can't change everything at once, because if we touch all centres with reform -- and reform is a kind of disorganisation -- this could be bad for the defence system," he said at the conference.
U.S. President Bill Clinton said last week he hoped to see new members in NATO by 1999 and Poland is widely assumed to be in the front rank of candidate countries.
